Types of Adverbs

Let us go ahead in Adverbs by learning its Types and with some examples.

Different types of Adverbs

Adverbs are categorised into different types according to their functions when used in a sentence. Given below are the different types of adverbs.

1. Adverbs of Time
2. Adverbs of Place
3. Adverbs of manner
4. Adverbs of frequency
5. Adverbs of degree

1. Adverbs of Time

Adverbs of Time tell us when something happens. Adverbs of time tell us when an action happened, but also for how long, and how often. Adverbs of time are usually placed at the end of a sentence.

I thought I could finish cleaning my house today.
Yesterday, Teena met Anu at the supermarket.
Sometimes, I hate her

2. Adverbs of Place

Adverbs that are employed in a sentence to describe the location or the place where an action is taking place are called adverbs of place. They answer the question ‘where’. They are mostly found after the main verb or the object in a sentence. They can also refer to distances or the movement of an object in a particular direction. Given below are examples of how adverbs of place can be used to depict the location of the action in a sentence.

The boy was asked to keep the cups here.
The little girl ran towards her mother the moment she saw her.
Robert stood outside the store.

3. Adverbs of Manner

An adverb of manner as “an adverb that shows how someone does something or how something happens. For example, in the sentences ‘Drive carefully’, ‘He talks too fast’, ‘The moon shone brightly’, and ‘I accidentally deleted the file’, ‘carefully’, ‘fast’, ‘brightly’ and ‘accidentally’ are manner adverbs.” The word ‘manner’, is defined as “the way in which something is done.” So an adverb of manner can be said to be one which depicts the way in which an action is done. Take a look at the following examples to learn how you can use adverbs of manner effectively.

He ran quickly.
I can write and listen to music simultaneously.
He swims really well.

4. Adverbs of Frequency

An adverb of frequency is used in a sentence to give more information about the verb, adjective or another adverb. Adverbs of frequency can be placed after the noun or pronoun that acts as the subject and before the verb if there is just one verb in a sentence. If there is more than one verb in a sentence (e.g., auxiliary verb), the adverb of frequency can be positioned before the main verb. Have a look at the following sentences to understand how an adverb of frequency can be used.

Ashish often likes to have food from hotels.
We never like to have litchi juice from any other store.
Wiley always buys groceries from the supermarket.

5. Adverbs of Degree

An adverb of degree is employed in a sentence to depict the intensity or degree of an adjective, verb or another adverb. It usually answers the question ‘to what extent’. They are normally positioned before the word (an adjective in most cases) they are modifying.Given below are some examples for how adverbs of degree can be used in sentences.

The coat was big enough for him.
Her dress was very elegant.
The soup was too hot for me to eat.
